verses.text:
Give me your heart, my son,
And let your eyes delight in my ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For a harlot is a deep pit
And an adulterous woman is a narrow well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely she lurks as a robber,
And increases the faithless among men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has woe? Who has sorrow?
Who has contentions? Who has complaining?
Who has wounds without cause?
Who has redness of eyes?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who linger long over wine,
Those who go to taste mixed wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
At the last it bites like a serpent
And stings like a viper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your eyes will see strange things
And your mind will utter perverse things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And you will be like one who lies down in the middle of the sea,
Or like one who lies down on the top of a mast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They struck me, but I did not become ill;
They beat me, but I did not know it.
When shall I awake?
I will seek another drink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be envious of evil men,
Nor desire to be with them;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For their minds devise violence,
And their lips talk of trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By wisdom a house is built,
And by understanding it is established;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And by knowledge the rooms are filled
With all precious and pleasant riches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A wise man is strong,
And a man of knowledge increases power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For by wise guidance you will wage war,
And in abundance of counselors there is victory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom is too exalted for a fool,
He does not open his mouth in the gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One who plans to do evil,
Men will call a schemer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The devising of folly is sin,
And the scoffer is an abomination to men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you are slack in the day of distress,
Your strength is limited.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Deliver those who are being taken away to death,
And those who are staggering to slaughter, Oh hold them back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you say, “See, we did not know this,”
Does He not consider it who weighs the hearts?
And does He not know it who keeps your soul?
And will He not render to man according to his work?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, eat honey, for it is good,
Yes, the honey from the comb is sweet to your taste;
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Do not lie in wait, O wicked man, against the dwelling of the righteous;
Do not destroy his resting place;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For a righteous man falls seven times, and rises again,
But the wicked stumble in time of calamity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not rejoice when your enemy falls,
And do not let your heart be glad when he stumbles;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Or the Lord will see it and be displeased,
And turn His anger away from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not fret because of evildoers
Or be envious of the wicked;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For there will be no future for the evil man;
The lamp of the wicked will be put out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My son, fear the Lord and the king;
Do not associate with those who are given to change,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For their calamity will rise suddenly,
And who knows the ruin that comes from both of them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These also are sayings of the wise.
To show partiality in judgment is not good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who says to the wicked, “You are righteous,”
Peoples will curse him, nations will abhor him;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But to those who rebuke the wicked will be delight,
And a good blessing will come upon them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He kisses the lips
Who gives a right answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause,
And do not deceive with your lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not say, “Thus I shall do to him as he has done to me;
I will render to the man according to his work.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I passed by the field of the sluggard
And by the vineyard of the man lacking sense,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
When I saw, I reflected upon it;
I looked, and received instruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“A little sleep, a little slumber,
A little folding of the hands to rest,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then your poverty will come as a robber
And your want like an armed man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These also are proverbs of Solomon which the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah, transcribed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is the glory of God to conceal a matter,
But the glory of kings is to search out a matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the heavens for height and the earth for depth,
So the heart of kings is unsearchable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take away the dross from the silver,
And there comes out a vessel for the smith;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take away the wicked before the king,
And his throne will be established in righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not claim honor in the presence of the king,
And do not stand in the place of great men;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For it is better that it be said to you, “Come up here,”
Than for you to be placed lower in the presence of the prince,
Whom your eyes have seen.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Argue your case with your neighbor,
And do not reveal the secret of another,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Or he who hears it will reproach you,
And the evil report about you will not pass away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like apples of gold in settings of silver
Is a word spoken in right circumstances.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like an earring of gold and an ornament of fine gold
Is a wise reprover to a listening ear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like the cold of snow in the time of harvest
Is a faithful messenger to those who send him,
For he refreshes the soul of his masters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like clouds and wind without rain
Is a man who boasts of his gifts falsely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By forbearance a ruler may be persuaded,
And a soft tongue breaks the bone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have you found honey? Eat only what you need,
That you not have it in excess and vomit it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let your foot rarely be in your neighbor’s house,
Or he will become weary of you and hate you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a club and a sword and a sharp arrow
Is a man who bears false witness against his neighbor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a bad tooth and an unsteady foot
Is confidence in a faithless man in time of trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like one who takes off a garment on a cold day, or like vinegar on soda,
Is he who sings songs to a troubled heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat;
And if he is thirsty, give him water to drink;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For you will heap burning coals on his head,
And the Lord will reward you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The north wind brings forth rain,
And a backbiting tongue, an angry countenance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is better to live in a corner of the roof
Than in a house shared with a contentious woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like cold water to a weary soul,
So is good news from a distant land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a trampled spring and a polluted well
Is a righteous man who gives way before the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is not good to eat much honey,
Nor is it glory to search out one’s own glory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a city that is broken into and without walls
Is a man who has no control over his spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like snow in summer and like rain in harvest,
So honor is not fitting for a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a sparrow in its flitting, like a swallow in its flying,
So a curse without cause does not alight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A whip is for the horse, a bridle for the donkey,
And a rod for the back of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not answer a fool according to his folly,
Or you will also be like him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Answer a fool as his folly deserves,
That he not be wise in his own eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He cuts off his own feet and drinks violence
Who sends a message by the hand of a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like the legs which are useless to the lame,
So is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like one who binds a stone in a sling,
So is he who gives honor to a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a thorn which falls into the hand of a drunkard,
So is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like an archer who wounds everyone,
So is he who hires a fool or who hires those who pass by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a dog that returns to its vomit
Is a fool who repeats his folly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you see a man wise in his own eyes?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sluggard says, “There is a lion in the road!
A lion is in the open square!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the door turns on its hinges,
So does the sluggard on his bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sluggard buries his hand in the dish;
He is weary of bringing it to his mouth again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sluggard is wiser in his own eyes
Than seven men who can give a discreet answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like one who takes a dog by the ears
Is he who passes by and meddles with strife not belonging to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a madman who throws
Firebrands, arrows and death,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So is the man who deceives his neighbor,
And says, “Was I not joking?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For lack of wood the fire goes out,
And where there is no whisperer, contention quiets down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like charcoal to hot embers and wood to fire,
So is a contentious man to kindle strife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The words of a whisperer are like dainty morsels,
And they go down into the innermost parts of the body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like an earthen vessel overlaid with silver dross
Are burning lips and a wicked heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who hates disguises it with his lips,
But he lays up deceit in his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he speaks graciously, do not believe him,
For there are seven abominations in his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though his hatred covers itself with guile,
His wickedness will be revealed before the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who digs a pit will fall into it,
And he who rolls a stone, it will come back on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A lying tongue hates those it crushes,
And a flattering mouth works ruin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not boast about tomorrow,
For you do not know what a day may bring forth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let another praise you, and not your own mouth;
A stranger, and not your own lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A stone is heavy and the sand weighty,
But the provocation of a fool is heavier than both of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wrath is fierce and anger is a flood,
But who can stand before jealousy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better is open rebuke
Than love that is concealed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Faithful are the wounds of a friend,
But deceitful are the kisses of an enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sated man loathes honey,
But to a famished man any bitter thing is sweet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a bird that wanders from her nest,
So is a man who wanders from his home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oil and perfume make the heart glad,
So a man’s counsel is sweet to his friend.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Be wise, my son, and make my heart glad,
That I may reply to him who reproaches me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A prudent man sees evil and hides himself,
The naive proceed and pay the penalty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take his garment when he becomes surety for a stranger;
And for an adulterous woman hold him in pledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who blesses his friend with a loud voice early in the morning,
It will be reckoned a curse to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A constant dripping on a day of steady rain
And a contentious woman are alike;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who would restrain her restrains the wind,
And grasps oil with his right hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Iron sharpens iron,
So one man sharpens another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who tends the fig tree will eat its fruit,
And he who cares for his master will be honored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As in water face reflects face,
So the heart of man reflects man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied,
Nor are the eyes of man ever satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The crucible is for silver and the furnace for gold,
And each is tested by the praise accorded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though you pound a fool in a mortar with a pestle along with crushed grain,
Yet his foolishness will not depart from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Know well the condition of your flocks,
And pay attention to your herds;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For riches are not forever,
Nor does a crown endure to all generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the grass disappears, the new growth is seen,
And the herbs of the mountains are gathered in,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lambs will be for your clothing,
And the goats will bring the price of a field,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And there will be goats’ milk enough for your food,
For the food of your household,
And sustenance for your maidens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wicked flee when no one is pursuing,
But the righteous are bold as a lion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By the transgression of a land many are its princes,
But by a man of understanding and knowledge, so it endures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A poor man who oppresses the lowly
Is like a driving rain which leaves no food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who forsake the law praise the wicked,
But those who keep the law strive with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Evil men do not understand justice,
But those who seek the Lord understand all things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Better is the poor who walks in his integrity
Than he who is crooked though he be rich.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who keeps the law is a discerning son,
But he who is a companion of gluttons humiliates his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who increases his wealth by interest and usury
Gathers it for him who is gracious to the poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who turns away his ear from listening to the law,
Even his prayer is an abomination.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who leads the upright astray in an evil way
Will himself fall into his own pit,
But the blameless will inherit good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The rich man is wise in his own eyes,
But the poor who has understanding sees through him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the righteous triumph, there is great glory,
But when the wicked rise, men hide themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who conceals his transgressions will not prosper,
But he who confesses and forsakes them will find compassion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How blessed is the man who fears always,
But he who hardens his heart will fall into calamity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a roaring lion and a rushing bear
Is a wicked ruler over a poor people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A leader who is a great oppressor lacks understanding,
But he who hates unjust gain will prolong his days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man who is laden with the guilt of human blood
Will be a fugitive until death; let no one support him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who walks blamelessly will be delivered,
But he who is crooked will fall all at once.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who tills his land will have plenty of food,
But he who follows empty pursuits will have poverty in plenty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A faithful man will abound with blessings,
But he who makes haste to be rich will not go unpunished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To show partiality is not good,
Because for a piece of bread a man will transgress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man with an evil eye hastens after wealth
And does not know that want will come upon him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who rebukes a man will afterward find more favor
Than he who flatters with the tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who robs his father or his mother
And says, “It is not a transgression,”
Is the companion of a man who destroys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An arrogant man stirs up strife,
But he who trusts in the Lord will prosper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who trusts in his own heart is a fool,
But he who walks wisely will be delivered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who gives to the poor will never want,
But he who shuts his eyes will have many curses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the wicked rise, men hide themselves;
But when they perish, the righteous increase.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man who hardens his neck after much reproof
Will suddenly be broken beyond remedy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the righteous increase, the people rejoice,
But when a wicked man rules, people groan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man who loves wisdom makes his father glad,
But he who keeps company with harlots wastes his wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king gives stability to the land by justice,
But a man who takes bribes overthrows it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man who flatters his neighbor
Is spreading a net for his steps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By transgression an evil man is ensnared,
But the righteous sings and rejoices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The righteous is concerned for the rights of the poor,
The wicked does not understand such concern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Scorners set a city aflame,
But wise men turn away anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When a wise man has a controversy with a foolish man,
The foolish man either rages or laughs, and there is no rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Men of bloodshed hate the blameless,
But the upright are concerned for his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A fool always loses his temper,
But a wise man holds it back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a ruler pays attention to falsehood,
All his ministers become wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The poor man and the oppressor have this in common:
The Lord gives light to the eyes of both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a king judges the poor with truth,
His throne will be established forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The rod and reproof give wisdom,
But a child who gets his own way brings shame to his mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the wicked increase, transgression increases;
But the righteous will see their fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Correct your son, and he will give you comfort;
He will also delight your soul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where there is no vision, the people are unrestrained,
But happy is he who keeps the law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A slave will not be instructed by words alone;
For though he understands, there will be no response.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you see a man who is hasty in his words?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who pampers his slave from childhood
Will in the end find him to be a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An angry man stirs up strife,
And a hot-tempered man abounds in transgression.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A man’s pride will bring him low,
But a humble spirit will obtain honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He who is a partner with a thief hates his own life;
He hears the oath but tells nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fear of man brings a snare,
But he who trusts in the Lord will be exalted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Many seek the ruler’s favor,
But justice for man comes from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An unjust man is abominable to the righteous,
And he who is upright in the way is abominable to the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The words of Agur the son of Jakeh, the oracle.
The man declares to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely I am more stupid than any man,
And I do not have the understanding of a man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Neither have I learned wisdom,
Nor do I have the knowledge of the Holy One.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has ascended into heaven and descended?
Who has gathered the wind in His fists?
Who has wrapped the waters in His garment?
Who has established all the ends of the earth?
What is His name or His son’s name?
Surely you know!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Every word of God is tested;
He is a shield to those who take refuge in Him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not add to His words
Or He will reprove you, and you will be proved a liar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Two things I asked of You,
Do not refuse me before I die:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
That I not be full and deny You and say, “Who is the Lord?”
Or that I not be in want and steal,
And profane the name of my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not slander a slave to his master,
Or he will curse you and you will be found guilty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a kind of man who curses his father
And does not bless his mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a kind who is pure in his own eyes,
Yet is not washed from his filthiness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a kind—oh how lofty are his eyes!
And his eyelids are raised in arrogance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a kind of man whose teeth are like swords
And his jaw teeth like knives,
To devour the afflicted from the earth
And the needy from among men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The leech has two daughters,
“Give,” “Give.”
There are three things that will not be satisfied,
Four that will not say, “Enough”:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sheol, and the barren womb,
Earth that is never satisfied with water,
And fire that never says, “Enough.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The eye that mocks a father
And scorns a mother,
The ravens of the valley will pick it out,
And the young eagles will eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are three things which are too wonderful for me,
Four which I do not understand:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The way of an eagle in the sky,
The way of a serpent on a rock,
The way of a ship in the middle of the sea,
And the way of a man with a maid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the way of an adulterous woman:
She eats and wipes her mouth,
And says, “I have done no wrong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Under three things the earth quakes,
And under four, it cannot bear up:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Under a slave when he becomes king,
And a fool when he is satisfied with food,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Under an unloved woman when she gets a husband,
And a maidservant when she supplants her mistress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Four things are small on the earth,
But they are exceedingly wise:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The ants are not a strong people,
But they prepare their food in the summer;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The shephanim are not mighty people,
Yet they make their houses in the rocks;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The locusts have no king,
Yet all of them go out in ranks;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lizard you may grasp with the hands,
Yet it is in kings’ palaces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are three things which are stately in their march,
Even four which are stately when they walk:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lion which is mighty among beasts
And does not retreat before any,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The strutting rooster, the male goat also,
And a king when his army is with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you have been foolish in exalting yourself
Or if you have plotted evil, put your hand on your mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: The words of King Lemuel, the oracle which his mother taught him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What, O my son?
And what, O son of my womb?
And what, O son of my vows?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not give your strength to women,
Or your ways to that which destroys kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is not for kings, O Lemuel,
It is not for kings to drink wine,
Or for rulers to desire strong drink,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For they will drink and forget what is decreed,
And pervert the rights of all the afflicted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give strong drink to him who is perishing,
And wine to him whose life is bitter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let him drink and forget his poverty
And remember his trouble no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Open your mouth for the mute,
For the rights of all the unfortunate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Open your mouth, judge righteously,
And defend the rights of the afflicted and needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An excellent wife, who can find?
For her worth is far above jewels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The heart of her husband trusts in her,
And he will have no lack of gain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She does him good and not evil
All the days of her life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She looks for wool and flax
And works with her hands in delight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She is like merchant ships;
She brings her food from afar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She rises also while it is still night
And gives food to her household
And portions to her maidens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She considers a field and buys it;
From her earnings she plants a vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She girds herself with strength
And makes her arms strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She senses that her gain is good;
Her lamp does not go out at night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She stretches out her hands to the distaff,
And her hands grasp the spindle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She extends her hand to the poor,
And she stretches out her hands to the needy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She is not afraid of the snow for her household,
For all her household are clothed with scarlet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She makes coverings for herself;
Her clothing is fine linen and purple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her husband is known in the gates,
When he sits among the elders of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She makes linen garments and sells them,
And supplies belts to the tradesmen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Strength and dignity are her clothing,
And she smiles at the future.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She opens her mouth in wisdom,
And the teaching of kindness is on her tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She looks well to the ways of her household,
And does not eat the bread of idleness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her children rise up and bless her;
Her husband also, and he praises her, saying:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Many daughters have done nobly,
But you excel them all.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Charm is deceitful and beauty is vain,
But a woman who fears the Lord, she shall be praised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Give her the product of her hands,
And let her works praise her in the gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator
